newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Bank Negara reserves rise to 70 bln rgt in '96.
newsitem.headline: Bank Negara reserves rise to 70 bln rgt in '96.

text.p: Bank Negara Malaysia said on Friday its reserves rose to 70 billion ringgit by the end of last year against 63.8 billion at the end of 1995.
The central bank said in its annual report for 1996 that the 6.2 billion ringgit rise last year followed two consecutive years of decline.
The reserves represent Malaysia's gold and foreign exchange, its reserve position with the International Monetary Fund and holdings of special drawing rights (SDRs).
The annual report said the rise in reserves was mainly due to a rise in long-term capital flows into the country.
Net private long-term capital flows in 1996 increased to 11.3 billion ringgit against 10.3 billion in the previous year.
This showed "strong net inflows of foreign direct investment (of 14.4 billion ringgit), primarily in the manufacturing (87 percent) and oil and gas (10 percent) sectors", it said.
However, this was partly offset by investments by Malaysians overseas of 6.3 billion ringgit during the year.

"The aggregate net inflow of long-term capital was not sufficient to finance the current account deficit, resulting in a deficit in the basic balance of 986 million ringgit (against 2.5 billion last year)," Bank Negara said.
The annual report estimated the 1996 current account deficit at 13 billion ringgit.
Official long-term capital inflows were also lower at 0.7 billion ringgit against 5.8 billion in 1995 because of higher prepayment of loans by the public sector.
